questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with bilateral knee, wrist, and hand pain and swelling over the past year. She experiences morning stiffness lasting over 30 minutes. Past medical history is significant for subclinical hyperthyroidism, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. She takes lisinopril and metformin. BMI is 32 kg/m². Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 78/min, blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination reveals bilateral knee effusions, with tenderness and limited range of motion. Both wrists and multiple metacarpophalangeal joints on both hands are enlarged and tender to palpation. Laboratory evaluation is unremarkable. X-ray of the right knee is shown below. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient’s underlying condition?


Taken from openi
questions.solution:
This patient's knee, wrist, and hand pain; along with morning stiffness, and chondrocalcinosis on knee imaging is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD) or pseudogout. In CPPD, calcium pyrophosphate crystals deposit in the joints and soft tissue causes joint pain and swelling. It most commonly affects the knees, wrists, and ankles. It predominantly affects older patients (age > 60 years); therefore, this patient’s age over 60 years is the most likely contributing risk factor.  

Pseudogout, or calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), may be asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging. It also can present as acute or chronic joint pain and swelling. It typically presents as acute monoarticular or polyarticular joint pain and swelling. However chronic pseudogout can involve the bilateral wrists and small joints of the hands and has been called “pseudo-rheumatoid arthritis" (pseudo-RA) when there is a non-erosive, inflammatory arthritis with CPP crystals found in joint fluid. Patients with chronic pseudogout can also present with chronic, degenerative arthritis, resembling osteoarthritis.  

Hypomagnesemia, hyperparathyroidism, and hemochromatosis have been associated with CPPD. Other important risk factors include trauma or surgery to the involved joints, as well as bisphosphonate use.  

Option Analysis

✅ Age over 60 years:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subclinical hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Hypothyroidism, and not hyperthyroidism, is associated with the development of CPDD.
❌ BMI >30 kg/m2:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Obesity is not a known risk factor for CPPD.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Studies have not shown an association between diabetes mellitus and CPPD.
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Biological males and females are affected equally by CPPD.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with fatigue and intermittent joint pain over the past few months. Recently, she has noticed oral ulcers. She takes no regular medications and has no known allergies. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, heart rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals skin pallor and three oral ulcers. She has tenderness and swelling over multiple metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of the hands bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation is notable for positive antinuclear antibodies and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Nodules over the extensor surfaces of the elbows
Well-defined, erythematous plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces of the elbows
Tender, erythematous nodules on the shins

questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of fatigue, joint pain, and oral ulcers coupled with her laboratory findings strongly suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). One of the classic dermatological manifestations of SLE is a discoid rash, which is considered chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus. The lesions of discoid lupus erythematous are typically erythematous indurated plaques with scale that may lead to scarring. They occur most often on sun-exposed areas, such as the face, neck, and scalp.

SLE is a complex, multisystem autoimmune disorder characterized by a wide range of clinical features. Key dermatological manifestations include the characteristic malar rash, appearing as butterfly-shaped erythema over the cheeks and bridge of the nose sparing the nasolabial folds, and discoid lupus erythematous. Joint symptoms are prevalent, with patients frequently experiencing pain and swelling, particularly in the small joints of the hands. Hematological abnormalities in SLE include anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Lupus nephritis is considered a severe complication of SLE and patients present with, manifests as proteinuria and hematuria. It can progress to renal failure. Neurological symptoms are varied but can include seizures and cognitive disturbances. Additionally, SLE can cause serositis (i.e. pericarditis and pleuritis), oral ulcers, alopecia, and photosensitivity.

Option Analysis

✅ Discoid rash on the scalp:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Splinter hemorrhages under the fingernails:
Incorrect: Splinter hemorrhages appear as small red or brown lines under the nails caused by small blood clots that have traveled to the small vessels. They are indicative of endocarditis and not systemic lupus erythematosus.  
❌ Nodules over the extensor surfaces of the elbows:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous nodules on extensor surfaces are characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis, not systemic lupus erythematosus.  
❌ Well-defined, erythematous plaques with silvery scale on the extensor surfaces of the elbows:
Incorrect: Erythematous plaques with silvery scale on extensor surfaces are a classic presentation of psoriasis and not systemic lupus erythematosus.  
❌ Tender, erythematous nodules on the shins:
Incorrect: Tender, erythematous nodules on the shins known as erythema nodosum are associated with inflammatory conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, infections, and sarcoidosis. This would be an uncommon presentation for systemic lupus erythematosus.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic with a one-week history of asymmetric joint pain that is most severe in the left knee and ankle as well as painful urination. He has no history of illness. He is sexually active with female partners and reports having unprotected intercourse recently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a warm, tender, swollen left knee and tenderness of the left ankle. Additionally, there is non-purulent conjunctivitis, white urethral discharge, and a rash on the palms and soles as seen in the image below. Laboratory studies are remarkable for an elevated ESR. An effusion is seen on X-ray of the knee. Rheumatoid factor is ordered, a genital swab is sent for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), and arthrocentesis of the left knee is performed. Which of the following test results is most likely?


Image courtesy of Wikimedia

choices.text: Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  10,000 cells/microL  Synovial culture  Negative
Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Gram positive cocci
Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Positive  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of asymmetric joint pain, dysuria, and unprotected intercourse. Coupled with the joint exam findings, conjunctivitis, and skin findings that are consistent with keratoderma blennorrhagicum, reactive arthritis is the most likely diagnosis. Laboratory studies would most likely demonstrate a negative rheumatoid factor, synovial fluid consistent with an inflammatory arthritis with a negative Gram stain, and nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) that is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis.    

In reactive arthritis, basic blood work may reveal a mild leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g. ESR, CRP). Radiographs of affected joints are generally nonspecific and are most often used to rule out other conditions (e.g. fracture, ankylosing spondylitis) but may demonstrate an effusion, periostitis, or calcaneal enthesitis and spurring. Additional studies may demonstrate a negative ANA and rheumatoid factor as well as HLA-B27 positivity in some individuals, which is a predisposing factor for reactive arthritis.  

For patients with joint effusions, arthrocentesis should be performed to rule out septic arthritis (e.g. gonococcal arthritis). In reactive arthritis, synovial studies are consistent with an inflammatory process (WBC count between 2,000–20,000 cells/microL), and Gram stain and culture are negative. As part of the workup, evaluating for a previous or current enteric or genitourinary infection can be helpful, though negative studies do not rule out the diagnosis of reactive arthritis. This evaluation may include a genital swab or stool cultures, based on the presenting signs and symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  10,000 cells/microL  Synovial culture  Negative:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Positive  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  15,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory studies is most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. However, the patient’s presentation of asymmetric arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is more consistent with reactive arthritis.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Gram positive cocci :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory studies is more consistent with septic arthritis. However, the patient’s presentation of asymmetric arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is more consistent with reactive arthritis.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Negative  NAAT  Negative  Synovial WBCs  1,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings would be more consistent with a noninflammatory joint condition, such as osteoarthritis. However, the patient’s presentation of asymmetric arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis is more consistent with reactive arthritis.
❌  Laboratory study  Result  Rheumatoid factor  Positive  NAAT  Positive for Chlamydia trachomatis  Synovial WBCs  110,000 cells/microL  Synovial Gram stain  Negative :
Incorrect: While the positive NAAT would be consistent with reactive arthritis from urethritis, which is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, the positive rheumatoid factor and significantly elevated synovial WBC count are not consistent with reactive arthritis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of asymmetric joint pain, particularly in her right knee and left ankle and foot. She had a recent episode of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, which resolved on its own. She has no significant past medical history or family history of autoimmune disorders. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. On examination, the right knee is swollen and warm. Laboratory tests are listed below. STI screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for managing this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory study  Result 
 ESR  72 mm/hr 
 CRP  3.97 mg/dL 
 ANA  Negative 
 Rheumatoid factor  Negative 
 HLA-B27  Positive 
 Synovial WBC count  10,000 cells/microL 
 Synovial Gram stain and culture  Negative
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing asymmetric oligoarthritis associated with a recent GI infection. This is most indicative of reactive arthritis, and the best next step in management is the use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as naproxen.  

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy. Patients present with joint inflammation after an enteric or genitourinary tract infection. Common causative organisms include Chlamydia trachomatis, Salmonella spp., and Shigella spp. Most associated gastrointestinal infections are self-limited and do not require treatment. However, if Chlamydia or Neisseria gonorrhoeae are identified on testing, appropriate antibiotic therapy should be initiated.    

NSAIDs are first-line therapy for managing the symptoms and inflammation of reactive arthritis. Patients often need two to four weeks of therapy. If symptoms do not respond, corticosteroids (either systemic or intra-articular) may be used. In cases that persist for ≥ 6 months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) should be considered, including methotrexate and sulfasalazine. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors are used in rare cases that are resistant to all other therapies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Oral naproxen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral prednisone:
Incorrect: Systemic corticosteroids are not the first-line treatment for reactive arthritis. Oral prednisone would be appropriate if symptoms persist despite NSAID therapy.
❌ Intra-articular triamcinolone:
Incorrect: Intra-articular corticosteroids are not the first-line treatment for reactive arthritis. Intra-articular corticosteroids would be appropriate if symptoms persist despite NSAID therapy.
❌ Oral doxycycline:
Incorrect: Oral doxycycline is used to treat Chlamydia trachomatis infections in patients with reactive arthritis. However, this patient’s testing does not indicate a current Chlamydia infection.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is not a first-line treatment for reactive arthritis. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs are reserved for cases that persist for ≥ 6 months.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to her physician for joint pain. The patient was diagnosed with psoriasis two years ago and was started on methotrexate. However, her skin lesions have not improved. Currently, the patient is having pain in the joints of both hands and fingers. Physical examination reveals inflammation of the distal interphalangeal joints, in addition to signs of joint destruction. The physician discusses a new medication with the patient called secukinumab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor
Inhibits the interaction of Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) with its receptors
Inhibits C5 complement protein and the activation of membrane attack complexes
It binds integrins of the blood vessel wall and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing joint pain as a result of psoriatic arthritis. The physician decided to start the patient on secukinumab, which is an interleukin-17A (IL-17A) inhibitor.

IL-17A inhibitors belong to a new class of medication, which are monoclonal antibodies that prevent the interaction of IL-17A with its receptors. Examples include secukinumab, brodalumab, and ixekizumab.  These medications were introduced after the discovery of the role of Th-17 cells in the pathogenesis of many inflammatory disorders. Th-17 produces IL-17, which is a proinflammatory cytokine that once produced, stimulates the recruitment of neutrophils and other inflammatory cells and induces sustained chronic inflammation. IL-17A has been implicated in the pathogenesis of many immune-mediated disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, crohn’s disease, and multiple sclerosis.

IL-17A inhibitors are currently under investigation and their uses are promising. One of the indications of Il-17A inhibitors is moderate to severe psoriasis, with or without arthritis. Additionally, there are studies underway to determine their efficacy in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disorder.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits the interaction of Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) with its receptors:
Incorrect: Anti-TNF monoclonal antibodies can be used in the treatment of psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. Examples include adalimumab and infliximab. However, secukinumab is an IL-17A inhibitor.  
❌ Inhibits C5 complement protein and the activation of membrane attack complexes:
Incorrect: Eculizumab binds to and inhibits C5, thereby inhibiting the activation of membrane attack complexes.  
❌ Inhibits interleukin-12/23:
Incorrect: Ustekinumab inhibits interleukin-12/13  
❌ It binds integrins of the blood vessel wall and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation:
Incorrect: Natalizumab binds integrins on the endothelial cells of the blood vessels and thereby inhibits the use of integrins by leukocytes to cross to the inflammation site.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic with an 8-month history of dry cough, mild shortness of breath, and fatigue. She has not experienced fever, chills, or weight loss. Her medical history is significant for mild, well-controlled hypertension for which she takes amlodipine. On physical examination, her vital signs are within normal limits. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral inspiratory crackles. No clubbing, cyanosis, or peripheral edema is noted. Bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy is present, with lymph nodes noted to be firm and nontender. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum calcium and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels. A chest x-ray is pending. What imaging finding is most likely to be seen on chest x-ray?

choices.text: Cavitary lesions in the upper lobes
Pulmonary nodules with a random distribution

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms (fatigue, cough, dyspnea), pulmonary and lymph node exam findings,  and laboratory studies (elevated ACE and calcium levels) are concerning for sarcoidosis. The most likely chest x-ray finding in patients with sarcoidosis is bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

Lymphadenopathy is a term used to describe lymph nodes that are of abnormal size or consistency. There are many potential causes, including inflammatory conditions, infections, and malignancy. The history and physical examination provide clues to help narrow the differential in patients who present with lymphadenopathy. While a more acute onset may suggest an infectious process, a longer time course is more consistent with malignancy, autoimmune, or chronic inflammatory conditions.

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease marked by non-caseating granulomas, most commonly affecting the lungs and lymphatic system. Lymphadenopathy occurs due to granulomas developing within the lymph nodes, which can then lead to lymphatic obstruction. Patients commonly present with symptoms such as persistent dry cough, shortness of breath, and fatigue, which can be accompanied by systemic signs like fever and weight loss. Imaging typically reveals bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and it can also show reticular opacities or nodular patterns. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels are often elevated in sarcoidosis due to the increased production of ACE by the epithelioid cells of the granulomas.
 
Statdx

Option Analysis

✅ Bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bilateral pleural effusions:
Incorrect: Bilateral pleural effusions are more commonly associated with conditions such as congestive heart failure, renal or liver disease, and infectious processes. Pleural effusions are uncommon in sarcoidosis.  
❌ Cavitary lesions in the upper lobes:
Incorrect: Cavitary lesions in the upper lobes are typically associated with certain infectious diseases like tuberculosis or necrotizing pneumonia, and certain vasculitides. These lesions are not common in sarcoidosis.  
❌ Pulmonary nodules with a random distribution:
Incorrect: Pulmonary nodules with a random distribution are more characteristic of metastatic diseases or certain infectious processes. This finding would be uncommon in sarcoidosis.  
❌ Unilateral focal lung consolidation:
Incorrect: Unilateral focal lung consolidation is typically seen in bacterial pneumonia, which is less consistent with the chronicity and the systemic signs presented in this case.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man patient presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right knee pain and swelling for the past 3 days. The patient has been unable to ambulate secondary to the pain. Past medical history includes hypertension, gout, diabetes, osteoarthritis managed with NSAIDs, and obesity. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is a palpable effusion, warmth, and marked swelling of the right knee when compared to the left knee. The patient is unable to flex and extend the knee without significant pain. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT without contrast of right knee
PA and lateral radiographs of right knee

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of unilateral knee swelling and pain in a native (non-prosthetic) joint. Given this patient's fever, effusion, limited range of motion, inability to bear weight, and significant pain with range of motion, septic arthritis is likely. The best next step in management is to obtain synovial fluid for analysis by performing an arthrocentesis.
 

Septic arthritis refers to joint inflammation that occurs when a pathogen invades the joint space. Once within the synovial cavity, pathogens trigger the immune system and stimulate the production of cytokines that can eventually result in joint damage. Septic arthritis can arise from infection in the adjacent bone, such as in osteomyelitis. It can also reach the joint through hematogenous spread from a distant infectious site in the body, or by direct inoculation which can occur as a complication of orthopedic surgery. Septic arthritis is usually monoarticular, affecting one large joint, and the diagnosis typically relies on synovial fluid aspiration and analysis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Arthrocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of intra-articular kenalog:
Incorrect: Administration of intra-articular kenalog is often part of the treatment of osteoarthritic pain. This patient has clinical examination findings that are concerning for septic arthritis, including fever and significant pain with range of motion, requiring arthrocentesis for diagnosis.  
❌ Administration of colchicine:
Incorrect: Colchicine is often used for the treatment of acute gouty arthritis. This patient has clinical examination findings that are concerning for septic arthritis, including fever and significant pain with range of motion, requiring arthrocentesis for diagnosis.  
❌ CT without contrast of right knee:
Incorrect: A CT scan of the knee without contrast is unlikely to provide useful diagnostic information for this patient who has symptoms and findings consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ PA and lateral radiographs of right knee:
Incorrect: Plain radiographs of the knee should be performed in cases of septic arthritis to evaluate for bone involvement and to provide a baseline, however when there is concern for septic arthritis, the diagnosis should first be made with arthrocentesis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, and redness in his left big toe. He reports that the pain started 8 hours ago and has progressively worsened. He has no fevers or chills. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is taking hydrochlorothiazide. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.4°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 133/79 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination is significant for tenderness, swelling, and erythema of the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot. There is limitation to both passive and active range of motion. Laboratory results are significant for mild leukocytosis and a serum uric acid level of 9.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Perform joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hyperuricemia and acute-onset pain, redness, and swelling in his left big toe consistent with the diagnosis of podagra or acute gout of the big toe.

The first step in treating an acute gout attack includes management of inflammation and pain with anti-inflammatory medications including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) which are considered first-line therapy. NSAIDs, such as indomethacin, naproxen, or ibuprofen, should be started within the first 24 hours of symptoms and continued for 7-10 days. Colchicine and oral or intra-articular glucocorticoids are alternatives for patients who cannot tolerate or have contraindications to NSAIDs such as those with a history renal disease, heart failure, peptic ulcer disease, NSAID hypersensitivity, or patients taking anticoagulation. All patients with gout should be counseled regarding lifestyle modifications, such as maintaining a healthy weight, maintaining adequate hydration, and modifying dietary habits (limiting high-purine foods, sugary beverages, and alcohol).

Urate-lowering therapy (ULT) with xanthine oxidase inhibitors, such as allopurinol or febuxostat, is indicated for patients with recurrent gout attacks, tophi, urate nephrolithiasis, stage 2 or worse chronic kidney disease, or evidence joint damage on imaging (e.g., punched out extra-articular erosions, soft tissue gouty tophi). These medications reduce the production of uric aci, and prevent future attacks. They should not be started during an acute gout attack as they can precipitate or worsen a flare due to mobilization of stored uric acid. To prevent this, patients should take low-dose anti-inflammatories for 2 to 4 weeks prior to the initiation of ULT.

Serum urate levels should be checked one month after initiating therapy with ULT. If the serum urate level is < 6 mg/dL, this indicates adequate response to treatment. In such cases, the patient should continue gout flare prophylaxis with low-dose colchicine (preferably) or an NSAID for up to six months. If the serum urate level is ≥ 6 mg/dL, adjustments to the treatment regimen may be needed while continuing gout flare prophylaxis. Adjustments include increasing the dose of the current xanthine oxidase inhibitor, switching to a different xanthine oxidase inhibitor, or adding a uricosuric agent such as probenecid. Once serum urate levels remain below target for six months, gout flare prophylaxis should be discontinued, and serum urate level should be followed annually.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe indomethacin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prescribe allopurinol:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a urate-lowering medication used for long-term prophylactic management of gout in patients with a history of recurrent gout attacks, chronic kidney disease, physical findings of tophi, or imaging findings of joint damage. It is not indicated in the acute management of a gout flare as it can worsen the flare.  
❌ Perform joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: While joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis can assist in making the diagnosis of gout, it is not required in patients with classic findings of podagra and risk factors for gout like the use of hydrochlorothiazide, as seen in this patient. Treatment with NSAIDs is indicated without need for further diagnostic testing.  
❌ Administer intra-articular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Intra-articular glucocorticoids may be used in the management of acute gout when other treatments are contraindicated or not tolerated. This patient has no contraindications to the use of NSAIDs.  
❌ Increase the dose of hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, can contribute to hyperuricemia and exacerbate gout. As such it is advisable to discontinue or decrease rather than increase the dose of hydrochlorothiazide in patients with gout.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of bilateral hand pain and morning stiffness for 6 months. The stiffness lasts for 60 minutes each morning, making it challenging for her to button her shirt and get ready. It gradually improves throughout the morning and is not as noticeable throughout the rest of the day. She also has fatigue which started 5 months ago, but she does not have fever, chills, weight loss, rashes, or hair loss. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 82/minute, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg. Physical examination of the hands shows tenderness and swelling with a “boggy” feel on palpation of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints of the hands. There is no warmth on palpation of the joints. Laboratory results are shown below.  Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Leukocyte count  
9,000/mm3   
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  
35 mm/hr  
Rheumatoid factor  
1:40
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 6-month history of bilateral joint pain in the hands associated with prolonged morning stiffness, and swelling and tenderness of the PIP and MCP joints. The patient’s findings are consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. The diagnosis of RA can be made clinically. Serologic testing for rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies can help support a diagnosis of RA. In this patient who has clinical findings consistent with RA but a normal RF, anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies should be ordered next. If positive they will support the RA diagnosis; however, they may not be positive in early disease and are not positive in all patients with RA. Serologic testing can help classify patients as having seronegative or seropositive disease and can help with prognosis. Patients with higher titers have more severe disease and a worse prognosis with a higher likelihood of developing erosive disease.
 

Other tests that are typically ordered when making the diagnosis of RA include ESR and CRP which are typically elevated in active disease and can help support the diagnosis and then be followed over time to assess response to treatment. Antinuclear antibody testing can be done to rule out SLE and other rheumatic diseases, though a portion of patients with RA will have a positive ANA. CBC can reveal anemia of chronic disease, and thrombocytopenia. X-ray can be performed to support the diagnosis, establish a baseline, and monitor disease over time. They can demonstrate ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and other deformities, periarticular soft tissue swelling, osteopenia, and erosions. Synovial fluid analysis can be helpful in ruling out other causes of arthritis such as septic arthritis or crystalline arthritis when the diagnosis is in doubt.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-double stranded DNA antibody is an antinuclear antibody that is highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This patient does not present with other features consistent with SLE like malar rash and alopecia and has joint involvement that is more typical of RA.  
❌ Uric acid level:
Incorrect: Uric acid level would be obtained in a patient suspected of having gout, which typically presents with monoarticular or polyarticular inflammatory arthritis that is not symmetrical. And joints are typically erythematous and warm on palpation. This patient’s symptoms and physical examination are more consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Anti-Ro antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-Ro antibody can be positive in a number of autoimmune disorders but is most commonly seen in patients with SLE and Sjorgren syndrome.  
❌ Anti-Smith antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-smith antibody is an antinuclear antibody that is highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus. This patient’s lack of rash and alopecia and bilateral symmetric polyarticular arthritis is more consistent with RA.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the office because of several months of low back and buttock pain. The patient reports that the pain is most severe early in the morning and gradually becomes better as the day progresses. The patient has no recent history of trauma. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for osteoarthritis in the patient’s parent. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the lower lumbar spine. Neurologic examination of the extremities is unremarkable. Plain x-ray of the spine is shown. The patient is initiated on a non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitor for his pain. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic back pain and radiography demonstrating “bamboo spine” consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. Reversible nonselective COX inhibitors (naproxen and ibuprofen) are the first line treatment for these patients.  

Reversible nonselective COX inhibitors reduce gastric mucosal protection via inhibition of COX-1 in the gastric mucosa and subsequently induce gastrointestinal side effects (including gastric ulcers and gastrointestinal bleeding). The risk of ulcers can be reduced by combining reversible nonselective COX inhibitors with a second medication like proton pump inhibitors to reduce gastric acid secretion.



Option Analysis

❌ Megaloblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Common risk factors for megaloblastic anemia include folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients with ankylosing spondylitis receiving treatment with non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors are not at increased risk of developing megaloblastic anemia.  
❌ Gastric cancer:
Incorrect: Although non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors have shown to increase the risk of gastric ulceration and bleeding, they do not increase the risk of developing gastric cancer.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect:  Non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors have not been shown to affect lipid levels.  
✅ Peptic ulcer :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recurrent nephrolithiasis:
Incorrect: Use of non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors does not increase the risk of developing nephrolithiasis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of knee pain for the past four months. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is associated with swelling at the knee following strenuous exertion. The pain is not associated with fever, rash or malaise. The patient was recently diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease but did not follow up with his gastroenterologist. He does not take any medications. BMI is 36.3 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a small effusion, tenderness and decreased range of motion of the left knee. Plain x-ray of the left knee joint shows narrowing of the joint space and osteophytes. The patient fails to demonstrate improvement in pain following initiation of a supervised exercise program. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to administer for the management of this patient’s pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis. In addition to a supervised exercise program, the patient should begin taking a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor (celecoxib), given his history of peptic ulcer disease.  

Celecoxib reversibly inhibits COX-2 and can treat pain and inflammation like other NSAIDs. It differs in that it does not affect COX-1, as it lacks the antiplatelet effects seen in aspirin and other non-selective COX inhibitors. Moreover, it does not compete with aspirin for COX-1, so it may be combined with aspirin without decreasing its antiplatelet effect.  

Reversible nonselective COX inhibitors reduce gastric mucosal protection via inhibition of COX-1, thus selective COX-2 inhibitors like celecoxib cause the least gastrointestinal side effects. They are recommended for use in patients at risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as prior peptic ulcer disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect: Naproxen reversibly inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. This medication should be avoided in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, as the inhibition of COX-1 reduces gastric mucosal protection.   
✅ Celecoxib:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin reversibly inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. This medication should be avoided in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, as the inhibition of COX-1 reduces gastric mucosal protection.   
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD), and serves as pharmacotherapy for patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis.  
❌ Sulfasalazine :
Incorrect: Sulfasalazine is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD), and serves as pharmacotherapy for patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right foot pain. The patient woke up this morning with pain associated with swelling and redness but no fever. The patient does not report any history of recent trauma. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows redness, warmth and a small effusion of the right great toe. A sample of synovial fluid shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy. The physician starts the patient on valdecoxib. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following clinical findings?

choices.text: Flank pain radiating to the groin
Chest pain radiating to the left arm
Overgrowth of gum tissue around the teeth

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute gout flare, which occurs due to monosodium urate deposition in joint spaces. The patient is started on valdecoxib, a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor.   

Highly selective COX-2 inhibitors increase the risk of arterial thrombosis, which can lead to myocardial infarction and/or stroke. The increased risk of arterial thrombosis is believed to be due to the COX-2 inhibitors having a greater inhibitory effect on endothelial prostacyclin (PGI2) formation than on platelet TXA2 formation. Prostacyclin promotes vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation, whereas TXA2 carries the opposite effects.  

These medications do not affect COX-1 and thus lack the antiplatelet effect seen in aspirin and other non-selective COX inhibitors. Moreover, selective COX-2 inhibitors do not compete with aspirin for COX-1, so they may be combined with aspirin without decreasing its antiplatelet effect.  

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric pain and tenderness:
Incorrect: Peptic ulcer disease usually presents with epigastric pain and tenderness. Gastrointestinal toxicity is less common with selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g. valdecoxib) and is unlikely to develop in this patient.  
❌ Flank pain radiating to the groin:
Incorrect: Although selective COX-2 inhibitors have been associated with increased risk of acute renal failure and acute interstitial nephritis, it does not increase the risk of nephrolithiasis.   
✅ Chest pain radiating to the left arm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ringing in ears:
Incorrect: Tinnitus (ringing in ears) is a common complication of salicylate overdose.   
❌ Overgrowth of gum tissue around the teeth:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a common complication of anti-epileptic drugs such as phenytoin or sodium valproate.
